objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to propose AutoLeadDesign, a framework that integrates large language models (LLMs) and chemical fragments to efficiently explore chemical space for lead compound design, aiming to outperform existing methods in de novo drug design.
objective.evidence: Here, we propose AutoLeadDesign, a lead compounds design framework that inspires extensive domain knowledge encoded in large language models with chemical fragments to progressively implement efficient exploration of vast chemical space.

knowledge_gap.answer: Existing computational methods struggle to effectively integrate domain-specific knowledge, limiting their capacity to identify novel lead compounds with validated binding modes and new scaffolds.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Prevailing computational methods, however, struggle to effectively integrate domain-specific knowledge, severely limiting their capacity to identify novel lead compounds with validated binding modes and new scaffolds.

answer: Integration of LLMs with chemical fragments to explore chemical space for lead compound design.
Closed-loop workflow that maps molecule space to fragment space and vice versa, facilitating comprehensive exploration.
Demonstration of superior performance in de novo drug design compared to baseline models.
evidence: We propose AutoLeadDesign, a framework that integrates LLM and chemical fragments to efficiently explore the chemical space for lead compounds design.
The closed-loop workflow is illustrated in Fig. 1, containing two key mapping.
Notably, AutoLeadDesign demonstrated superior performance compared to other baseline models in de novo drug design.

steps.step: Decompose molecules into fragments using BRICS.
steps.evidence: The strategy employed in this study is based on BRICS (Breaking of Retrosynthetically Interesting Chemical Substructures).

steps.step: Update fragment library based on docking scores.
steps.output: Filtered library containing top-k highest-affinity fragments.
steps.evidence: We established a filtered library containing the top-k highest-affinity fragments selected from the global fragment pool.

steps.step: Sample key fragments and generate novel compounds using LLM.
steps.input: Selected fragments based on binding contributions.
steps.output: Novel compounds added to the compound library.
steps.evidence: These selected fragments are incorporated into a predefined prompt to guide a LLM in generating novel compounds.

steps.output: Updated compound library for further iterations.
steps.evidence: The newly designed molecules are added to the compound library for further iterative execution.

tools.name: DeepSeek-v3
tools.description: Used for generating novel compounds by guiding LLM with sampled molecular fragments.
tools.evidence: The large language model (LLM) employed in our study is DeepSeek-v3.

tools.name: smina
tools.description: Used for docking simulations to approximate Gibbs free energy changes during ligand-receptor binding.
tools.evidence: We employed smina (a fork of Autodock Vina focused on improving scoring functions and energy minimisation) to approximate the Gibbs free energy changes during ligand-receptor binding.
